body_html:
Hey @jasnow to get rid of the additional commits make sure your master is even with the master from this repository. Your current repo here: https://github.com/jasnow/rgsoc-teams has the additional commits that you don't want to have.
As your last changes are not so big, I would suggest you to

  • create a new for of this repo
  • create a new feature branch: git branch -b fix/time-zones
  • apply your changes here and commit them
  • push them to your fork: git push origin fix/time-zones
  • open a new PR

The other way would be that you save your changes in a branch locally. Then reset your master to the current master, make a new feature branch and cherry-pick the existing last commit 7bcade4 on your new branch and push it and PR it.
Depending on how you want to do it I can elaborate the second approach more.

In general always also on your fork try to work in a feature branch and keep the master up to date with the main repo.

Hope this helps a bit

body:
Hey @jasnow to get rid of the additional commits make sure your master is even with the master from this repository. Your current repo here: https://github.com/jasnow/rgsoc-teams has the additional commits that you don't want to have.
As your last changes are not so big, I would suggest you to 
- create a new for of this repo
- create a new feature branch: `git branch -b fix/time-zones`
- apply your changes here and commit them
- push them to your fork: `git push origin fix/time-zones`
- open a new PR

The other way would be that you save your changes in a branch locally. Then reset your master to the current master, make a new feature branch and cherry-pick the existing last commit `7bcade4` on your new branch and push it and PR it.
Depending on how you want to do it I can elaborate the second approach more.

In general always also on your fork try to work in a feature branch and keep the master up to date with the main repo.

Hope this helps a bit
